intro: Lycopodioides borealis, commonly known as the northern clubmoss, is a rare and ancient plant belonging to the family Lycopodiaceae. It is characterized by its small, scale-like leaves and a sporophyte that produces spores in specialized structures called sporangia. This plant thrives in cool, moist environments, typically found in boreal forests and high-altitude regions. Its reproductive cycle is closely tied to the seasonal changes in its habitat, with spore release occurring during the late summer or early autumn. Due to its limited distribution and specific ecological requirements, Lycopodioides borealis is considered a sensitive indicator of environmental health.
